uniol.apt.adt.automaton

Class FiniteAutomatonUtility

  • java.lang.Object
    • uniol.apt.adt.automaton.FiniteAutomatonUtility

  • public class FiniteAutomatonUtility
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility functions for constructing and working with FiniteAutomaton instances.
    Author:
    Uli Schlachter

      • union

        public static FiniteAutomaton union(FiniteAutomaton a1,
                                    FiniteAutomaton a2)
        Get a finite automaton accepting the union of the languages of two automatons. A word is in the union of the languages if it is in at least one of the individual languages.
        Parameters:
        a1 - The first automaton of the union.
        a2 - The second automaton of the union.
        Returns:
        An automaton accepting the union.

        Parameters:

      • intersection

        public static FiniteAutomaton intersection(FiniteAutomaton a1,
                                           FiniteAutomaton a2)
        Get a finite automaton accepting the intersection of the languages of two automatons. A word is in the intersection of the languages if it is in all of the individual languages.
        Parameters:
        a1 - The first automaton of the intersection.
        a2 - The second automaton of the intersection.
        Returns:
        An automaton accepting the intersection.

      • negate

        public static DeterministicFiniteAutomaton negate(DeterministicFiniteAutomaton a)
        Get a finite automaton accepting the negation of the language of the given automaton. A word is in the negation of the language if is is not in the language itself.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton whose language is to negate.
        Returns:
        An automaton accepting the negation.

      • concatenate

        public static FiniteAutomaton concatenate(FiniteAutomaton a1,
                                          FiniteAutomaton a2)
        Get a finite automaton accepting the concatenation of the languages of two automatons. A word is in the concatenation if it can be split into two words so that the first word is accepted by the first automaton and the second word by the second automaton.
        Parameters:
        a1 - The first automaton of the concatenation.
        a2 - The second automaton of the concatenation.
        Returns:
        An automaton accepting the concatenation.

      • kleeneStar

        public static FiniteAutomaton kleeneStar(FiniteAutomaton a)
        Get a finite automaton accepting the kleene star of the language of an automaton. The kleene star iterates the language of an automaton. It starts with the language containing just the empty word and iteratively adds the concatenation of the result so far and the language itself.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton to iterate
        Returns:
        An automation accepting the kleene star closure.

      • kleenePlus

        public static FiniteAutomaton kleenePlus(FiniteAutomaton a)
        Get a finite automaton accepting the kleene plus of the language of an automaton. The kleene plus iterates the language of an automaton. It starts with the language itself and iteratively adds the concatenation of the result so far and the language itself.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton to iterate
        Returns:
        An automation accepting the kleene plus closure.

      • repeat

        public static FiniteAutomaton repeat(FiniteAutomaton a,
                                     int min,
                                     int max)
        Get a finite automaton accepting repeatitions of the language of an automaton.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton to repeat
        min - minimum number of repeatitions
        max - maximum number of repeatitions
        Returns:
        An automation accepting the repeatitions.

      • optional

        public static FiniteAutomaton optional(FiniteAutomaton a)
        Get a finite automaton accepting a word accepted by the given automaton or the empty word.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton
        Returns:
        An automaton accepting the empty word or a word accepted by the given automaton.

      • isWordInLanguage

        public static boolean isWordInLanguage(FiniteAutomaton a,
                                       java.util.List<java.lang.String> word)
        Test if a given word is accepted by a given finite automaton.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton to use.
        word - The word to check
        Returns:
        true if and only if the word is accepted by the automaton.

      • constructDFA

        public static DeterministicFiniteAutomaton constructDFA(FiniteAutomaton a)
        Construct a deterministic finite automaton from a general finite automaton via the powerset construction.
        Parameters:
        a - the automaton to determinize
        Returns:
        A deterministic finite automaton accepting the same language

      • minimize

        public static DeterministicFiniteAutomaton minimize(FiniteAutomaton a)
        Get the unique deterministic automaton with the minimal number of states that accepts the same language as the given automaton.
        Parameters:
        a - the automaton to minimize
        Returns:
        The minimal automaton for the language

      • languageEquivalent

        public static boolean languageEquivalent(FiniteAutomaton a1,
                                         FiniteAutomaton a2)
        Test if two automaton are language equivalent. Automatons are language equivalent if they accept the same language.
        Parameters:
        a1 - The first automaton to test with
        a2 - The second automaton to test with
        Returns:
        true if and only if both automaton accept the same language.

      • getDifferenceAutomaton

        public static FiniteAutomaton getDifferenceAutomaton(FiniteAutomaton a1,
                                                     FiniteAutomaton a2)
        Return a finite automaton that accepts all words which are only accepted by one of the automatons. This constructs (a1 minus a2) union (a2 minus a1).
        Parameters:
        a1 - The first automaton to test with
        a2 - The second automaton to test with
        Returns:
        An automaton that accepts the difference of the two languages.

      • findWordDifference

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> findWordDifference(FiniteAutomaton a1,
                                                                  FiniteAutomaton a2)
        Find a word that is only accepted by one of the automatons.
        Parameters:
        a1 - The first automaton to test with
        a2 - The second automaton to test with
        Returns:
        A word that is only accepted by one of the automatons

      • findPredicateWord

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> findPredicateWord(FiniteAutomaton a,
                                                                 org.apache.commons.collections4.Predicate<java.util.List<java.lang.String>> prefixPredicate,
                                                                 org.apache.commons.collections4.Predicate<java.util.List<java.lang.String>> wordPredicate)
        Find a word whose prefixes (including the word) conform to a given predicate and which itself also conforms to a second predicate. This method uses a depth-first search. A breath-first search would use more memory.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton whose accepted words should get checked.
        prefixPredicate - The predicate to check the prefixes.
        wordPredicate - The predicate to check the words.
        Returns:
        A word which conforms to the predicates.

      • prefixLanguageLTS

        public static TransitionSystem prefixLanguageLTS(FiniteAutomaton a)
        Construct a transition system that describes the prefix language of the given finite automaton. For this, the minimal DFA is calculated and transformed.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton whose prefix language should be generated.
        Returns:
        A transition system where sequences are enabled that correspond to prefixes of words which are accepted by a.

      • fromPrefixLanguageLTS

        public static FiniteAutomaton fromPrefixLanguageLTS(TransitionSystem lts)
        Construct a finite automaton from a transition system. Each sequence that reaches at least some state will be accepted by the automaton. Each sequence which reaches no state will be rejected.
        Parameters:
        lts - The transition system to transform.
        Returns:
        A finite automaton for the LTS' prefix language.

      • fromLTS

        public static FiniteAutomaton fromLTS(TransitionSystem lts,
                                      java.util.Collection<State> finalStates)
        Construct a finite automaton from a transition system with final states. Each sequence that reaches one of the final states will be accepted. All other sequences are rejected.
        Parameters:
        lts - The transition system to transform.
        finalStates - Sequences reaching a state from this collection are accepted.
        Returns:
        A finite automaton for the LTS' language with the given final states.

      • renderToGraphviz

        public static java.lang.String renderToGraphviz(FiniteAutomaton aut)
        Render a finite automaton in the Graphviz file format.
        Parameters:
        aut - The automaton to render
        Returns:
        The automaton in the Graphviz file format.

      • statesIterable

        public static java.lang.Iterable<uniol.apt.adt.automaton.State> statesIterable(FiniteAutomaton a)
        Get an Iterable iterating over all of the automaton's states. The initial state will be the first state returned by the iterable's iterators.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton whose states should be iterated
        Returns:
        An iterable over the automaton's states.

      • statesIterable

        public static java.lang.Iterable<DFAState> statesIterable(DeterministicFiniteAutomaton a)
        Get an Iterable iterating over all of the automaton's states. The initial state will be the first state returned by the iterable's iterators.
        Parameters:
        a - The automaton whose states should be iterated
        Returns:
        An iterable over the automaton's states.
